text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Declining oxygen and high phosphorus levels pose risk to Gulf of Finland, environment officials say.
- President Martti Ahtisaari said in Lapland Finland must honour its international obligations towards indigenous people.
- Government expected to award nationwide commercial television licence next week. @
- One in every five school children in Helsinki is an immigrant.
- Women account for a quarter of all management level employees in Finland, survey shows. Equality ombudsman says she is not clapping yet.
KAUPPALEHTI
- Finance ministry preparing to ease value-added tax on small firms as of the beginning of 1998. @
- Nokia has "cut the umbilical cord with Motorola," with the share rising 20 percent since early August while the American rival's share price has declined.
DEMARI
- Parliamentary foreign affairs committee says decision-makers should keep human rights in mind when awarding export permits to weapons manufacturers.
- Labour sports federation CSIT is moving its headquarters to Helsinki from Brussels. @
AAMULEHTI
- Baltic ferries plan to curb boisterous behaviour on cruises by imposing new minimum age limit of 23 years on pasengers.
- Justice ministry proposal would enable officials to release prisoners with life sentences after 11 years.
- Man who imported hundreds of kilos of gold bullion to Finland has left 7.3 million markka in taxes unpaid.
- Finland's big three forest industry firms watching anxiously to see whether fine paper price hikes will hold. @
- The northernmost factory in the EU -- a jigsaw puzzle plant -- will start operations at the beginning of next year in Finland's northernmost municipality, Utsjoki.
- Proposed Nordic natural gas network is on European Union's list of important energy projects for the near future.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Brewers' federation demands lower tax on beer -- worried about Sweden's tax break for beer.
- Chernobyl nuclear reactor leak caused no increase in radiation levels in Finland, official says.
--Helsinki Newsroom +358-0-680 50 235
